content: honeycomb scarf this scarf features a super simple slip_stitch pattern and faux i-cord edging plus with big needles you will fly through this knit quickly the texture is drape-y yet very cozy and the slightly more masculine fabric makes it a great unisex scarf yarn cascade 220 200m/100g or any 8ply/dk to 10ply/worsted weight yarn quantity 2 3 skeins or approximately 400m 600m sizes normal large large size is pictured dimesions 19cm x 157cm 26 5cm x 200cm approximately needles 6mm needles if you are a tight knitter we recommend you go up a size as the fabric might curl if too dense gauge 18 stitches and 30 row to 10cm in pattern materials yarn needle for weaving in ends abbreviations sts stitches k knit p purl rs right side ws wrong side sl1 slip one purl-wise wyif with yarn in front bring yarn to front of work as if to purl slip next 2 stitches purl-wise note instructions for the different sizes are shown in square brackets as follows normal large 1 designed by emily bolduan © maker maker 2019 pattern cast on 35 53 sts or any odd number row 1 rs k to last 2sts slip 2 wyif row 2 ws k3 sl1 k1 to last 2sts slip 2 wyif row 3 as row 1 row 4 k4 sl1 k1 to last 3sts k1 slip 2 wyif repeat these 4 row until you have used up all of your yarn leaving enough to bind off or until desired length finishing having just worked a rs row bind off on wrong side of work then weave in ends blocking we like to finish our knits off by blocking them which just means to wash them gently and dry flat this lets all of your stitches relax and settle down and gives you a chance to straighten out your edges giving a neat finish we think blocking is magic step 1 soak your knit in a bucket filled with lukewarm water for at least 20 minutes you can add some wool wash or conditioner if you like but if you are using a soft wool you don t need to step 2 squeeze out as much water as you can by hand but don t wring it then wrap your knit in a towel and squeeze out even more this will help to cut down your drying time step 3 place your knit somewhere flat to dry preferably in a warm spot we like to use a yoga mat towel or foam mats then straighten out your knit so it looks how you want it to pinning any corners if necessary with ordinary pins just let it dry and then you re done if you have trouble telling what row you are on it can help to look at your fabric for some clues the stitches that are being slipped will alternate from row to row meaning you will slip the stitches that were not slipped our website is
